record.title: MAKING INDIVIDUALS EMPLOYED BY ROOSEVELT CAMPOBELLO INTERNATIONAL PARK COMMISSION ELIGIBLE TO OBTAIN FEDERAL HEALTH INSURANCE
record.narrative:
MAKING INDIVIDUALS EMPLOYED BY ROOSEVELT CAMPOBELLO INTERNATIONAL PARK COMMISSION ELIGIBLE TO OBTAIN FEDERAL HEALTH INSURANCE -- (House of Representatives - July 30, 2007)

[Page: H8830]

speaking.paragraph: Mr. Speaker, I ask unanimous consent that the Committee on Oversight and Government Reform be discharged from further consideration of the Senate bill (S. 1099) to amend chapter 89 of title 5, United States Code, to make individuals employed by the Roosevelt Campobello International Park Commission eligible to obtain Federal health insurance, and ask for its immediate consideration in the House.

record.narrative: The Clerk read the title of the Senate bill.
record.chair: Is there objection to the request of the gentleman from Illinois?
record.narrative: The Clerk read the Senate bill, as follows:

Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled,

   SECTION 1. HEALTH INSURANCE.

    Section 8901(1) of title 5, United States Code, is amended--

    (1) in subparagraph (H), by striking "and" at the end;

    (2) in subparagraph (I), by inserting "and" after the semicolon; and

    (3) by inserting before the matter following subparagraph (I) the following:
"(J) an individual who is employed by the Roosevelt Campobello International Park Commission and is a citizen of the United States,".<ul>

speaking.paragraph: Mr. Speaker, S. 1099 is a bill that makes a U.S. citizen employed by the Roosevelt Campobello International Park Commission eligible to obtain Federal health insurance.
Mr. Speaker, I urge the swift passage of this bill.
The Senate bill was ordered to be read a third time, was read the third time, and passed, and a motion to reconsider was laid on the table.
N O T I C E

Incomplete record of House proceedings. Except for concluding business which follows,

   today's House proceedings will be continued in the next issue of the Record.
